comments.author: thebrownproject
comments.text:
[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

**WebSocketManager (frontend/lib/websocket.ts, 223 lines):**
- ConnectionStatus type at line 13: 6 states (disconnected, connecting, authenticating, sprite_waking, connected, error)
- send() at line 103 returns boolean (true if ws open, false otherwise). Task changes return type to "sent"|"queued"|"dropped".
- No message queue exists. No close code handling. onclose at line 78 does not read event.code (just calls scheduleReconnect unconditionally).
- authenticate() at line 140 is fire-and-forget: getToken() at line 142 has no try/catch. If it throws, unhandled promise rejection, no status transition.
- handleSystemMessage at line 179: handles connected, sprite_waking, sprite_ready, error. No case for reconnect_failed (protocol.ts line 312 defines it, SystemEvent union at ws-protocol.ts:312 includes it).
- backoffMs reset on sprite_ready at line 189.
- intentionalClose flag at line 48 prevents reconnect on user-initiated disconnect.
- handlers Map at line 50 has a TODO note: not currently used for message routing.

**ws-provider.tsx (313 lines):**
- WebSocketContextValue at line 22: exposes status, error, connect, disconnect, send, debugLog.
- send() wrapper at line 289: returns boolean from manager.send(). Logs outbound only when ok=true.
- onStatusChange callback at line 268: sets status/error state, shows toast.error on error status (added by task 14.7 at line 273).
- No reference to send return value beyond passing boolean upstream. Provider does not expose manager directly.
- Auto-connects on mount at line 302. Destroys on unmount.

**chat-bar.tsx (395 lines):**
- Line 36: destructures { send, status } from useWebSocket().
- Line 38: isConnected = status === "connected". Used at line 77 as gate for handleSend.
- sendMessage() at line 53: calls addMessage() unconditionally (optimistic), then calls send(). Ignores send() return value.
- handleSend() at line 74: checks isConnected before calling sendMessage(). If not connected, silently does nothing (no toast, no queue).
- File upload via useFileUpload hook at line 37: sendUpload() at use-file-upload.ts:29 also ignores send() return value.

**Protocol types (frontend/types/ws-protocol.ts):**
- SystemEvent at line 312: includes "reconnect_failed" -- already in the type union.
- parseMessage at line 567: parses raw string into ProtocolMessage.
- isSystemMessage at line 484: validates against the SystemEvent array at line 487 which includes "reconnect_failed".

**Bridge reconnect.ts (225 lines):**
- reconnect_failed sent at line 173 (sprite failed to wake) and line 211 (reconnect error).
- Buffer: MAX_BUFFER=50, BUFFER_TTL_MS=60000. This is the Bridge-side buffer for browser-to-Sprite messages during reconnect.
- The task calls for a SEPARATE frontend queue (browser-to-Bridge) with 100 messages, 60s TTL.

**Bridge close codes (bridge/src/index.ts + auth.ts):**
- 4001: auth timeout (index.ts:100), first message not auth (index.ts:141), bad JWT (auth.ts:135).
- 4003: user not found (auth.ts).
- 1011: infra error (auth.ts:18).
- Frontend websocket.ts onclose at line 78 does NOT read event.code currently. Needs CloseEvent.code access to detect 4001.

**Existing UI patterns:**
- Spinner component: frontend/components/ui/spinner.tsx (Loader2Icon with animate-spin).
- GlassPill: frontend/components/ui/glass-pill.tsx (rounded-full glass container, used in DesktopTopBar right side for system tray).
- Sonner toasts: already wired in ws-provider.tsx:273 (connection error) and use-file-upload.ts (upload errors). Import pattern: `import { toast } from "sonner"`.
- Glass design tokens in globals.css: --glass-bg, --glass-border, --text-primary, --text-secondary, --text-muted.
- Icons barrel: AlertCircle, Circle, Refresh, Loader2 available. No Wifi/Signal/Cloud/Plug icons. Would need adding to icons/index.ts if needed.

**Testing infrastructure:**
- Vitest 3.0 with jsdom environment (frontend/vitest.config.ts).
- No existing WebSocketManager unit tests anywhere. Tests will need to be created from scratch.
- Chat-bar tests at __tests__/chat-bar.test.tsx mock useWebSocket with static { status: "connected", send: vi.fn(() => true) }.
- Store tests exist at lib/stores/__tests__/ (desktop-store-merge, chat-store-merge, clamp-position, voice-store).

**Desktop page.tsx (95 lines):**
- Provider nesting at line 69: WebSocketProvider > MaybeVoiceProvider > GlassTooltipProvider > CardOverlayProvider.
- Connection status indicator would go inside WebSocketProvider but visible above all other content. DesktopTopBar at line 76 is the natural anchor point.

## Implementation Guidance

**T3.1 (connection status indicator):**
- Subscribe to status from useWebSocket() in the indicator component.
- Transient disconnect suppression: use a setTimeout/useRef pattern -- delay showing "reconnecting" by 5s after status leaves "connected". If status returns to connected within 5s, suppress the indicator entirely.
- DesktopTopBar (desktop-top-bar.tsx) right side has a GlassPill system tray at line 85. The status indicator can be placed as a sibling or inside this tray area.
- Alternatively, a fixed-position pill/banner independent of the top bar (simpler, fewer coupling concerns).

**T3.2 (message queue in WebSocketManager):**
- Add a queue array and constants (MAX_QUEUE=100, QUEUE_TTL_MS=60000) to WebSocketManager class.
- Change send() return type from boolean to "sent"|"queued"|"dropped".
- Queue logic: if ws not open but not in error/terminal state, push to queue. If queue full, drop oldest and return "dropped". If message TTL expired on flush, discard.
- Flush on sprite_ready: handleSystemMessage at line 188 (sprite_ready case) is where queue drains.
- Two separate buffers documented in code: this frontend queue (browser-to-Bridge) vs Bridge buffer in reconnect.ts (Bridge-to-Sprite). Comment explicitly.

**T3.3 (chat-bar optimistic send fix):**
- sendMessage() at chat-bar.tsx:53 currently calls addMessage() before send(). Reverse: call send() first, check return value, then add message to store (with appropriate status based on return).
- send() return type changes from boolean to string ("sent"|"queued"|"dropped"), so the check changes from boolean to checking the return value.

**T3.4 (reconnect_failed handling):**
- handleSystemMessage at websocket.ts:179 needs a new case for "reconnect_failed". Transition to "error" status with the message payload.

**T3.5 (auth rejection 4001 terminal):**
- ws.onclose at websocket.ts:78 receives CloseEvent. Change signature from `() =>` to `(event: CloseEvent) =>`. Check event.code === 4001. If so, set intentionalClose=true (or similar flag) to prevent reconnect, then setStatus("error", "Authentication failed").
- The authenticate() method at line 145 already closes with code 4001 when no token available. This change catches the Bridge-initiated 4001 close.

**T3.9 (Sprite cold-start feedback):**
- sprite_waking status already transitions at websocket.ts:185. The status indicator from T3.1 should show "Connecting to your workspace..." when status is sprite_waking.

**T3.10 (authenticate() fix):**
- Wrap getToken() call at websocket.ts:142 in try/catch. On error: setStatus("error", "Failed to get auth token"), close socket. Currently only handles null return (line 143-146), not thrown exceptions.

**T3.7 partial (send-failure toasts):**
- In chat-bar.tsx sendMessage() or handleSend(), after checking send() return value, if "dropped": `toast.error("Message could not be sent", { id: "send-failed" })`. Pattern matches existing toast usage in ws-provider.tsx:273.

**ws-provider.tsx send() wrapper:**
- Currently at line 289, wraps manager.send() and returns boolean. Needs to update return type to match new "sent"|"queued"|"dropped" signature. The WebSocketContextValue interface at line 27 declares `send: ... => boolean` and needs updating.

## Risks

- **No existing WebSocketManager tests**: All queue behavior, TTL eviction, flush-on-sprite_ready, close-code handling need new test files. Use jsdom environment with mocked WebSocket global.
- **ws-provider send() return type change**: Every caller of send() currently treats return as boolean. Callers: chat-bar.tsx:62, desktop-top-bar.tsx:59/77, use-file-upload.ts:29, desktop-card.tsx (if any). All need updating for string return type, or at minimum, truthy/falsy checks still work since "sent"/"queued" are truthy and only "dropped" indicates failure (but undefined/false would be falsy).
- **CloseEvent vs Event**: Browser WebSocket onclose provides CloseEvent with code property. The current handler ignores parameters entirely. TypeScript may need explicit typing.
- **Queue flush ordering**: Messages queued while disconnected flush on sprite_ready. But state_sync also arrives on sprite_ready (from ws-provider.tsx:180). Flushed messages may conflict with fresh server state. Document this interaction in code comments.
- **10 pre-existing test failures**: Voice/STT tests are broken (noted in tasks 14.7 and 14.8). New tests should avoid voice module dependencies.

- `frontend/app/(desktop)/desktop/page.tsx` is `'use client'` (line 1). It is the only file in `frontend/app/(desktop)/desktop/`.
- No layout.tsx exists in `(desktop)/` route group. Root layout is at `frontend/app/layout.tsx`.
- Next.js App Router convention: `error.tsx` at `app/(desktop)/desktop/error.tsx` catches React errors within that route segment. Must export a default client component with `{ error: Error & { digest?: string }, reset: () => void }` props.

**Sonner toasts (T3.7):**
- Sonner v2.0.7+ installed. `<Toaster />` already rendered in root layout (`frontend/app/layout.tsx:89`).
- Zero `toast()` calls exist in the entire frontend codebase. The `toast` function is exported from `'sonner'` directly: `import { toast } from 'sonner'`.
- `sonner.tsx` is a shadcn managed file (do not modify). It uses Lucide icons and next-themes theming.

**Connection error sources (where to add toasts):**
- `frontend/components/desktop/ws-provider.tsx:248-251` -- `onStatusChange` callback sets `status` and `error` state. When `status === 'error'`, the `error` string contains the message (e.g., 'Failed to get auth token' from `websocket.ts:144`, or Sprite error message from `websocket.ts:196`).
- The `error` state and `status` are exposed via `WebSocketContext` (line 285) but NO component currently reads the `error` value to display it.
- Connection errors to toast: status transition to `'error'` in the `onStatusChange` callback (ws-provider.tsx:248-251). This is the single point where all connection errors surface.

**File upload error sources (where to add toasts):**
- `frontend/hooks/use-file-upload.ts:14-19` -- two `console.error` calls for type rejection and size rejection. Both return `false` but no UI feedback.
- `use-file-upload.ts` is called from two places:
  - `frontend/components/desktop/chat-bar.tsx:109` (`handleFileChange`)
  - `frontend/components/desktop/desktop-viewport.tsx:313` (drag-and-drop)
- Neither caller checks the `sendUpload()` return value.
- The hook could import `toast` from `'sonner'` directly, or callers could check the return value. Adding toasts inside the hook itself (replacing console.error) covers both call sites in one place.
- NOTE: `reader.onload` calls `send()` (line 28) but ignores its return value. If WebSocket is not connected, the upload silently fails. Per task description, send-failure toasts are deferred to the Frontend Connection Status task.

**System error visibility (T3.8):**
- `frontend/components/desktop/chat-panel.tsx:23` -- system messages render as `text-center font-mono text-[11px] text-white/25`. This is nearly invisible (11px, 25% opacity white on dark background).
- Agent errors flow through `ws-provider.tsx:171-172` as `role: 'system'` with content `[error] ...`. Tool calls also as `role: 'system'` with content `[tool] ...`.
- Both error and tool system messages use the same styling. The fix should differentiate: error messages need visible styling, tool messages can stay subtle.

## Implementation Guidance

**error.tsx (T3.6):**
- Create `frontend/app/(desktop)/desktop/error.tsx` with `'use client'` directive.
- Export default component accepting `{ error, reset }` props per Next.js convention.
- Style with existing glass design tokens from `globals.css` (--glass-bg, --glass-border, --text-primary, --text-secondary).
- Include a retry/reset button. The `reset()` function re-renders the route segment.
- Keep minimal: heading, error message, reset button. No need for elaborate UI.

**Sonner toasts (T3.7):**
- Connection error toast: In `ws-provider.tsx`, inside the `onStatusChange` callback (line 248-251), add `toast.error(err)` when `err` is truthy. Import `{ toast } from 'sonner'`.
- Upload error toasts: In `use-file-upload.ts`, replace `console.error` calls (lines 15, 19) with `toast.error('Unsupported file type. Use PDF, PNG, or JPEG.')` and `toast.error('File too large. Maximum size is 25MB.')`. Import `{ toast } from 'sonner'`.
- Send-failure toasts are explicitly deferred to the Frontend Connection Status task (stackdocs-m7b.14.6).

**System error visibility (T3.8):**
- In `chat-panel.tsx`, the system message branch is at lines 20-25. The fix target is line 23: `text-[11px] text-white/25`.
- Differentiate errors from tool messages by checking `message.content.startsWith('[error]')`. Errors: visible styling (e.g., `text-xs text-red-400/80`). Tools: can keep subtle (e.g., `text-xs text-white/40`).

## Risks

- **Toast theming**: The `<Toaster />` uses next-themes + CSS vars (--popover, --popover-foreground). The desktop uses a dark theme. Verify toast visibility on the glass UI background. If toasts look wrong, the Toaster component props (position, theme override) may need adjusting -- but `sonner.tsx` is shadcn-managed (do not modify), so adjustments would need to happen in `layout.tsx` via props.
- **Duplicate toasts on reconnect**: Connection errors may fire repeatedly during backoff reconnect cycles. The `onStatusChange` callback fires on every status transition. Consider deduplication (e.g., only toast on transition TO error, not on every reconnect attempt). Sonner has built-in dedup via `toast.error(msg, { id: 'connection-error' })`.
- **No layout.tsx in (desktop)/**: The error boundary at `desktop/error.tsx` only catches errors within the `desktop/page.tsx` route. Errors in root layout or providers above it won't be caught. This matches the task scope (desktop route protection), but a `global-error.tsx` at the app root would be needed for full coverage (not in scope for this task).

comments.text:
[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

**Target files (all in frontend/):**
- `components/desktop/ws-provider.tsx` (294 lines) - WebSocket message handler, state_sync at lines 178-238
- `lib/stores/desktop-store.ts` (264 lines) - Zustand persisted store, mergeCards at lines 161-174, clampCardPosition at line 30
- `lib/stores/chat-store.ts` (103 lines) - Zustand persisted store, setMessages at line 65 (wholesale replace)
- `app/(desktop)/desktop/page.tsx` (93 lines) - Desktop page, CardLayer at lines 23-40, DEMO_CARDS at lines 42-48, seeding useEffect at lines 55-64

**Protocol types:** `types/ws-protocol.ts` - StatusUpdate defined at line 250-257, included in SpriteToBrowserMessage union at line 342. Bridge protocol.ts has matching definition.

**Existing tests:** `lib/stores/__tests__/desktop-store-merge.test.ts` (112 lines) - 6 tests for mergeCards. Tests currently assert local-only cards ARE deleted (line 59-73) and (0,0) cards ARE overwritten (line 75-85). These tests must be updated to match new behavior.

**Related component:** `components/desktop/desktop-card.tsx` - TEMPLATE_WIDTHS map at line 23-29 (document:400, metric:300, table:600, article:500, data:400). Used at line 201 for rendering width.

## Implementation Guidance

**T4.1 (isAgentStreaming reset):** Add `chat.setAgentStreaming(false)` at ws-provider.tsx:181, before any other state_sync processing. The `chat` variable is already obtained at line 181.

**T4.2 (archivedStackIds reconcile):** ws-provider.tsx:184-185 calls `store.setStacks(stacks)` and `store.setActiveStackId(active_stack_id)` but never touches `archivedStackIds`. The server stacks array is the truth. After setStacks, filter archivedStackIds to only contain IDs that exist in the server stacks array. desktop-store.ts has no existing action for this; add a `reconcileArchivedStacks` action or inline the filter in the state_sync handler via `useDesktopStore.setState()`.

**T4.3 (mergeCards (0,0) sentinel + local-only deletion):**
- Current mergeCards (desktop-store.ts:161-174) only iterates `incoming` keys. Local-only cards not in incoming are dropped (this is actually the intended server-authoritative behavior per spec).
- The (0,0) sentinel bug: line 167 checks `existing.position.x \!== 0 || existing.position.y \!== 0` -- a card legitimately at (0,0) gets its position overwritten. Fix options per spec: add a `userPositioned: boolean` flag to DesktopCard interface, set it true in moveCard action (line 197), check that flag instead of (0,0) in mergeCards. No `userPositioned` field exists anywhere currently.
- The existing test at desktop-store-merge.test.ts:75-85 tests the (0,0) overwrite behavior and will need updating.
- The test at line 59-73 asserts local-only cards are removed -- this behavior is correct per spec (server is authoritative) but contradicts the spec note about 'local-only card deletion'. Clarify with spec: if server is authoritative, local-only cards SHOULD be deleted.

**T4.4 (preserve user messages during state_sync):**
- ws-provider.tsx:236 calls `chat.setMessages(mapped)` which wholesale replaces. chat-store.ts:65 confirms: `setMessages: (messages) => set({ messages, chips: [] })`.
- Need a merge function: keep local messages with timestamps newer than the state_sync payload timestamp (`message.timestamp` from the state_sync message), dedup by message id. ChatMessage has `id` and `timestamp` fields (chat-store.ts:8-13).
- The state_sync message itself has a `timestamp` field (from WebSocketMessageBase).

**T4.5 (status message handler):**
- ws-provider.tsx switch statement at line 102 handles: canvas_update, agent_event, state_sync, system. No `case 'status'` branch exists.
- StatusUpdate payload has: `document_id`, `status` (DocumentStatus), `message?`. DocumentStatus = 'processing' | 'ocr_complete' | 'completed' | 'failed'.
- No document status tracking exists in any store yet. Options: add to desktop-store (update card metadata), or add a new documents store. The simplest approach per the existing pattern: use toast notifications for status updates (like the error handler at line 253-255), and/or update card data if a matching card_id exists.

**T4.6 (remove demo cards):**
- page.tsx:55-64 useEffect seeds DEMO_CARDS on every mount via `setCards(seeded)`. This runs BEFORE state_sync arrives, then state_sync mergeCards overwrites. But the seeding also sets wallpaper to 'solid-white' (line 56).
- Remove the entire DEMO_CARDS constant (lines 42-48) and the useEffect (lines 55-64). Or gate behind `process.env.NODE_ENV === 'development'`. The wallpaper set should also be removed or gated separately.

**T4.7 (clampCardPosition width):**
- clampCardPosition at desktop-store.ts:30 defaults cardWidth to CARD_WIDTH (380 = medium). The addCard action (line 178) and moveCard action (line 202) call it without cardWidth.
- TEMPLATE_WIDTHS is in desktop-card.tsx:23-29 (component file, not store). To use in the store, either: export TEMPLATE_WIDTHS from desktop-card.tsx and import in store (creates circular dep risk), or move TEMPLATE_WIDTHS to desktop-store.ts alongside CARD_WIDTHS, or pass cardWidth explicitly at call sites.
- addCard (line 178) has access to the card object which has `size` and `cardType`. Can compute width inline: `card.cardType ? TEMPLATE_WIDTHS[card.cardType] : CARD_WIDTHS[card.size]`.
- moveCard (line 197-203) only receives position and cardHeight, not cardWidth. Signature needs extending or card lookup needed.

**T4.8 (CardLayer filter by active stack):**
- CardLayer at page.tsx:23-40 uses `useDesktopStore((s) => s.cards)` which returns ALL cards.
- `useCardsForActiveStack()` selector exists at desktop-store.ts:256-264, returns `DesktopCard[]` filtered by activeStackId.
- Replace the store selector in CardLayer with `useCardsForActiveStack()`. Note: it returns an array, not a Record, so the `Object.values(cards).map()` at line 33 becomes `cards.map()`.

## Risks

- **T4.3 spec ambiguity:** Spec says 'fix local-only card deletion' but also says 'server state as authoritative'. These contradict -- if server is authoritative, local-only cards should be deleted. The existing test at desktop-store-merge.test.ts:59-73 already tests this deletion behavior. Builder needs clarity on intent.
- **T4.5 missing document state:** No store tracks document processing status. The status handler needs somewhere to put the data. If no document UI exists yet, a toast notification may be the minimum viable handler.
- **T4.7 circular dependency risk:** TEMPLATE_WIDTHS lives in desktop-card.tsx which imports from desktop-store.ts. Moving widths to the store avoids the circular import.
- **T4.3 persist migration:** Adding `userPositioned` to DesktopCard requires a persist migration (currently at version 2, desktop-store.ts:231). Existing persisted cards need `userPositioned: false` as default.
- **Test updates required:** desktop-store-merge.test.ts tests 75-85 and 59-73 assert current behavior that T4.3 will change.

title: Sprite Gateway and Runtime Hardening
description:
**Goal:** Fix gateway scoping, background task lifecycle, send_fn safety, timeouts, and proper shutdown.

**Wave:** 3 (UX + Runtime)
**Size:** L
**Depends on:** Sprite Ping/Pong and Protocol Types

**Files:**
- Modify: `sprite/src/server.py`, `sprite/src/gateway.py`, `sprite/src/runtime.py`

**Steps:**
1. T6.1: Move mission_lock to server scope. Create in main(), pass to each SpriteGateway constructor.
2. T6.2: Add background task registry. Store extraction task handles. Cancel on shutdown/disconnect.
3. T6.3: Add _is_connected flag to AgentRuntime. Check before every _send_event() call.
4. T6.4: Guard send_fn swap during reconnect. Add generation counter or async lock.
5. T6.5: Add await server.wait_closed() after server.close(). Cancel active handlers on SIGINT/SIGTERM.
6. T6.6: Add 120s readline timeout. Wrap reader.readline() in asyncio.wait_for().
7. T6.7: Add timeouts to SDK calls. Wrap both _client.query() AND receive_response() in asyncio.wait_for().
8. T6.11: Fix double SIGTERM. Guard stop.set_result() with if not stop.done().

**Tests:**
- [ ] mission_lock created once in main() and shared across all gateway instances
- [ ] Background extraction tasks tracked and cancelled on shutdown/disconnect
- [ ] _send_event checks is_connected flag; handles disconnect gracefully
- [ ] send_fn swap uses generation counter; in-flight sends during reconnect do not crash
- [ ] server.wait_closed() called; active handlers cancelled on shutdown
- [ ] reader.readline() has 120s timeout
- [ ] Both _client.query() and receive_response() wrapped in asyncio.wait_for()
- [ ] Double SIGTERM does not raise InvalidStateError
close_reason: 8/8 tests pass. Shared mission_lock, task tracking+cancel, connected guard, generation counter, wait_closed, readline timeout, SDK timeouts, double SIGTERM guard.

comments.author: thebrownproject
comments.text:
[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

### T6.1: mission_lock scoping
- `sprite/src/gateway.py:126` — `self.mission_lock = asyncio.Lock()` created per-SpriteGateway instance
- `sprite/src/server.py:52` — new SpriteGateway created per connection (`handle_connection`)
- `sprite/src/server.py:73` — `main()` is where the lock should be created (line 75-118)
- SpriteGateway constructor at gateway.py:119-129 accepts `send_fn`, `runtime`, `workspace_db` — needs new `mission_lock` param
- Background extraction at gateway.py:294 uses `self.mission_lock` — this is the stale-lock scenario the task describes

### T6.2: background task registry
- `sprite/src/gateway.py:239-241` — `asyncio.create_task(self._run_extraction(...))` fire-and-forget, no handle stored
- Only one place creates background tasks: `_handle_file_upload` at line 239
- `_run_extraction` (lines 283-306) acquires mission_lock and calls runtime.handle_message
- server.py:113 calls `server.close()` then `runtime.cleanup()` — no task cancellation happens
- server.py:68 finally block only closes the writer, no task cleanup

### T6.3: _is_connected flag in AgentRuntime
- `sprite/src/runtime.py:306-323` — `_send_event()` calls `self._send(to_json(event))` with no guard
- `_send` is the raw send_fn (line 57: `self._send = send_fn`)
- `_indirect_send` at line 79-82 also delegates to `self._send` — canvas tools use this
- When TCP disconnects, `self._send` still points to old connection's writer.write+drain which will throw
- `_query_and_stream` at line 250-258 loops over receive_response calling _handle_sdk_message which calls _send_event — entire loop will cascade failures

### T6.4: send_fn swap safety
- `sprite/src/runtime.py:130-137` — `update_send_fn()` does simple assignment: `self._send = send_fn`
- Called from server.py:50 on each new connection
- No lock or generation counter — if _send_event is mid-await on old send_fn's drain(), the swap races
- `_indirect_send` at line 79-82 also reads `self._send`, same race condition

### T6.5: server.wait_closed() and handler cancellation
- `sprite/src/server.py:113-114` — `await stop` then `server.close()` but NO `await server.wait_closed()`
- No tracking of active connection handler tasks — `asyncio.start_server` manages them internally
- Signal handler at line 79: `loop.add_signal_handler(sig, lambda: stop.set_result(None))`
- After server.close(), lines 115-118 cleanup runtime and databases — but connection handlers may still be running

### T6.6: readline timeout
- `sprite/src/server.py:58` — `line = await reader.readline()` with no timeout
- The StreamReader has a 50MB limit (line 111) but no time limit
- Half-open TCP connections will block here forever

### T6.7: SDK call timeouts
- `sprite/src/runtime.py:252` — `await self._client.query(prompt)` no timeout
- `sprite/src/runtime.py:254` — `async for message in self._client.receive_response():` no timeout
- These are the two blocking SDK calls that can hang indefinitely
- `_start_session` (line 154) and `_continue_session` (line 235) both funnel through `_query_and_stream`

### T6.11: double SIGTERM
- `sprite/src/server.py:79` — `loop.add_signal_handler(sig, lambda: stop.set_result(None))`
- `stop` is an `asyncio.Future()` (line 75) — calling `set_result()` twice raises `InvalidStateError`
- Both SIGTERM and SIGINT use the same lambda, and receiving either signal twice triggers the bug

## Implementation Guidance

### mission_lock (T6.1)
- Create `mission_lock = asyncio.Lock()` in `main()` at server.py ~line 100 (after DB init, before runtime creation)
- Pass it to `handle_connection` which passes it to SpriteGateway constructor
- SpriteGateway.__init__ should accept `mission_lock: asyncio.Lock` and store as `self.mission_lock` (replacing the self-created one at line 126)
- Tests in test_server.py:41 create SpriteGateway directly — update fixtures to pass a shared lock
- Tests in test_server.py:120 (test_mission_lock_serialization) already test lock behavior — update to verify shared lock works across gateway instances

### background task registry (T6.2)
- Add `self._tasks: set[asyncio.Task] = set()` to SpriteGateway.__init__
- In `_handle_file_upload` (gateway.py:239), store task handle: `task = asyncio.create_task(...); self._tasks.add(task); task.add_done_callback(self._tasks.discard)`
- Add `async def cancel_tasks(self)` method that cancels all in self._tasks
- Call cancel_tasks from server.py handle_connection finally block (line 68) and from main() shutdown sequence

### _is_connected flag (T6.3)
- Add `self._is_connected: bool = False` to AgentRuntime.__init__ (runtime.py ~line 57)
- Set True in update_send_fn (line 130)
- Set False when disconnect detected (called from server.py finally block — add `runtime.mark_disconnected()`)
- Check in _send_event (line 306): early return with log warning if not connected
- Also check in _indirect_send (line 79) for canvas tool safety

### send_fn swap (T6.4)
- Add `self._send_generation: int = 0` to AgentRuntime.__init__
- In update_send_fn: increment generation, store new send_fn
- In _send_event: capture generation before await, check after — if changed, log warning and skip (message went to new connection)
- Alternatively use an asyncio.Lock — simpler but adds latency to every send

### server shutdown (T6.5)
- Track handler tasks: store each `asyncio.create_task(handle_connection(...))` in a set in main()
- On shutdown: cancel all handler tasks, then `await server.wait_closed()`
- Or: use `server.close(); await server.wait_closed()` and let the framework cancel handlers — but spec says to explicitly cancel

### readline timeout (T6.6)
- Replace `line = await reader.readline()` with `line = await asyncio.wait_for(reader.readline(), timeout=120)`

title: Add Welcome Message for New Users
description:
**Goal:** New users receive an agent-generated greeting explaining Stackdocs capabilities.

**Steps:**

- [ ] Existing user does NOT receive welcome
- [ ] Welcome appears as normal agent message
close_reason: Closed

comments.author: thebrownproject
comments.text:
[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

**Target file:** `sprite/src/gateway.py` (407 lines)

- `_handle_state_sync_request()` at line 384-389: Currently just calls `send_state_sync(workspace_db, send_fn)` and returns. This is where the welcome check goes per the task description.
- `state_sync_request` is the browser-initiated path. The server also sends state_sync on initial TCP connect at `sprite/src/server.py:59` (outside gateway). The welcome trigger belongs in the gateway handler since that is what the browser requests.
- `_run_extraction()` at line 258-284 is the direct pattern to follow: acquires `mission_lock`, calls `runtime.handle_message()`, wrapped in `asyncio.create_task()`. The welcome message should use the same structure.
- `self._tasks` set (line 80) + `add_done_callback(self._tasks.discard)` pattern (line 216) tracks background tasks for cleanup. Use this for the welcome task.
- `self.runtime` is available on the gateway instance (line 83). It has `handle_message(text, request_id=None)` as the entry point.
- `self.mission_lock` is available (line 79). Must be held during `runtime.handle_message()` to prevent race with user missions.
- `self._workspace_db` is available (line 81). Has `get_chat_history(limit=100)` at `database.py:472-478` which returns list of dicts from `chat_messages` table, ordered by id ASC. Empty list means new user.

**Chat history check:** `WorkspaceDB.get_chat_history()` at database.py:472 does `SELECT * FROM chat_messages ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT ?` then reverses. For the "is new user" check, `limit=1` is sufficient -- empty result means no chat history.

**State sync function:** `send_state_sync()` at state_sync.py:96-102 is a standalone async function. It creates a default "My Stack" if none exist (line 34-37). After it completes, chat_history will be available in the state_sync payload sent to frontend.

**Agent message persistence:** When the agent responds via `runtime.handle_message()`, the RuntimeMessage handler at runtime.py:344-345 calls `workspace_db.add_chat_message("agent", turn_response)`. User messages are persisted by `_handle_mission()` at gateway.py:157. So after welcome, the next state_sync will include the welcome in chat_history, preventing re-trigger.

**Test patterns:**
- `tests/test_gateway_canvas.py` is the canonical gateway test file. Uses `tmp_path` fixture for real WorkspaceDB, `AsyncMock` for send_fn, `MagicMock` for runtime.
- Gateway fixture pattern: `SpriteGateway(send_fn=mock_send, runtime=MagicMock(), workspace_db=workspace_db)` at test_gateway_canvas.py:43.
- `_run_extraction` tests (lines 205-254) verify: runtime.handle_message called, lock held during call, error handling. Same assertions needed for welcome.
- For testing welcome specifically: set `runtime.handle_message = AsyncMock()`, call `_handle_state_sync_request()`, verify handle_message was called (or not, for existing user).

## Implementation Guidance

- In `_handle_state_sync_request()` (line 384), after the `send_state_sync()` call, check `self._workspace_db.get_chat_history(limit=1)`. If empty and `self.runtime` is available, fire `asyncio.create_task(self._send_welcome_message())`.
- New method `_send_welcome_message()` follows `_run_extraction()` pattern: `async with self.mission_lock: await self.runtime.handle_message(welcome_prompt)`.
- Track the task in `self._tasks` with `add_done_callback(self._tasks.discard)` (same as line 212-216).
- Welcome prompt should be a short agent instruction (2-3 sentences explaining capabilities, no card creation).
- `server.py:59` also calls `send_state_sync()` directly on TCP connect, but does NOT go through gateway. The welcome check only triggers on `state_sync_request` message type. Consider whether `server.py` should also trigger welcome (initial connect = first time user opens app). If the frontend sends `state_sync_request` on every connect, the gateway path is sufficient. If the frontend only receives `state_sync` passively on connect (server.py:59), the welcome would never trigger via gateway. **The browser protocol type list includes state_sync_request (bridge protocol.ts:360), but the frontend ws-provider does not appear to send it explicitly -- state_sync comes from server.py on connect.** This means the welcome check may need to go in `server.py:handle_connection()` after the `send_state_sync()` call instead of (or in addition to) the gateway handler.

## Risks

- **Trigger location ambiguity:** Task says "In _handle_state_sync_request()", but the frontend may never send state_sync_request -- it receives state_sync passively from server.py on connect. Builder should verify by checking bridge forwarding and frontend behavior, or add the welcome check in BOTH server.py (after line 59) and gateway.py (in _handle_state_sync_request). The server.py path would need access to workspace_db.get_chat_history and the mission_lock + runtime already available there.
- **Race condition on reconnect:** Sleep/wake reconnections also trigger state_sync (server.py:59). If welcome is in server.py, an existing user reconnecting would pass the chat history check (non-empty) and correctly skip. But if chat_messages were cleared somehow, they would get an unexpected welcome.
- **Welcome persists as agent message:** runtime.handle_message streams agent_event messages to frontend AND persists to chat_messages via the ResultMessage handler. This is the desired behavior -- welcome appears in chat and subsequent checks see non-empty history.

- Sprite gateway.py:150-178 handles mission: sends ack, persists to chat, calls `runtime.handle_message()`

Per plan: connect WS, send auth token, wait for `sprite_ready`, send `mission`, wait for `agent_event`, verify round-trip, exit 0.
- Auth requires a real Clerk JWT. Options: (a) use Clerk Backend API `createSignInToken` to mint a test token, (b) accept token as env var `CLERK_TEST_TOKEN`, (c) use Clerk test mode session tokens. Option (b) is simplest for a gated smoke test.

- `bridge/tests/updater.test.ts:89-101` — tests verify the update flow calls `spriteExec` with `mkdir -p`, `deployCode`, `writeFile` (VERSION), and `chown`. If apt-get is added to updater, a new test assertion should verify it runs.
- 180 tests currently passing across 14 test files.

## Implementation Guidance

- **bootstrap.ts line 173**: Append `poppler-utils` to the existing apt-get install command. The pattern is a single `spriteExec` call with chained apt-get. Result: `sudo apt-get update -qq && sudo apt-get install -y -qq python3-venv poppler-utils 2>&1 | tail -1`
- **bootstrap.ts line 19**: Bump `CURRENT_VERSION` from `'0.3.1'` to a new version (plan suggests `'0.4.0'`).
- **updater.ts**: The plan notes that the updater only deploys code, not apt packages. For existing Sprites, the plan offers two options: (a) add apt-get to updater, (b) manually install. The task description says to either extend the updater or manually install. Adding a `spriteExec` call with `sudo apt-get update -qq && sudo apt-get install -y -qq poppler-utils 2>&1 | tail -1` before or after the `deployCode` call in `checkAndUpdate()` would follow the existing pattern.
- **updater.test.ts line 13**: Update the hardcoded `CURRENT_VERSION` mock value to match the new version.
- Follow existing test pattern: add assertion that `spriteExec` was called with a command containing `poppler-utils` (similar to the `rm -rf` stale files check at line 127-132).

## Risks

- **Updater apt-get adds latency**: apt-get update + install adds 5-15s to every lazy update cycle. This runs once per version bump (not every connect), and is wrapped in try/catch best-effort, so it won't block connections. But it will slow the first reconnect after a deploy.
- **Existing Sprites**: Only one or two test Sprites exist. Manual install via `sprite exec -s <name> -- bash -c 'sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y poppler-utils'` is viable if updater extension is deferred.
- **apt-get idempotency**: `apt-get install -y` is idempotent (skips already-installed packages), so running it on every update is safe but slow. Consider checking `which pdftotext` first to skip if already present.

7. Send `sprite_ready` system message to browser
8. Replay buffered messages (max 50 messages, 60s TTL)
9. Implement keepalive: ping Sprite every 15s during active browser sessions, stop on disconnect
10. Handle race conditions: multiple wake attempts, messages during reconnect

comments.text:
[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

### Existing Sprite Code
- `sprite/src/server.py` (59 lines) -- WS server, creates SpriteGateway per connection
- `sprite/src/gateway.py` (113 lines) -- message router with stub handlers, uses asyncio.Lock for serial mission/heartbeat execution
- `sprite/src/protocol.py` (582 lines) -- Python dataclasses mirroring bridge/src/protocol.ts
- `sprite/src/__init__.py` (1 line) -- empty package init
- Tests in `sprite/tests/test_server.py` (182 lines) -- WS integration + unit tests using pytest-asyncio

### database.py Does NOT Exist Yet
- No `sprite/src/database.py` file found in the codebase. This is a green-field create.
- No `sprite/tests/test_database.py` either.

### Dependencies Already Configured
- `sprite/requirements.txt` includes `aiosqlite>=0.20.0` (line 2)
- `sprite/pyproject.toml` sets `asyncio_mode = "auto"` for pytest-asyncio (tests can use plain `async def`)
- Dev deps: `pytest>=8.0`, `pytest-asyncio>=0.24.0`

### Canonical DB Path: `/workspace/agent.db`
- **NOT `/workspace/data/stackdocs.db`** as stated in `docs/specs/SCHEMA.md` (line 82) -- SCHEMA.md is stale here
- Canonical source: v2 spec (spec.md line 260), bootstrap code (`bridge/src/bootstrap.ts` line 49), ops docs (`docs/ops/golden-checkpoint.md` line 29+94)
- The golden sprite already has a DB initialized at `/workspace/agent.db`

### Bootstrap Schema (Source of Truth for Table DDL)
The bootstrap script in `bridge/src/bootstrap.ts` (lines 47-94) defines the exact schema already deployed to golden sprites:

**documents**: id TEXT PK, filename TEXT, file_path TEXT, file_size_bytes INT, mime_type TEXT, status TEXT (CHECK constraint), display_name TEXT, tags TEXT, summary TEXT, session_id TEXT, uploaded_at TEXT, updated_at TEXT

**ocr_results**: id TEXT PK, document_id TEXT NOT NULL UNIQUE FK, ocr_file_path TEXT, page_count INT, processing_time_ms INT, model TEXT, created_at TEXT

**extractions**: id TEXT PK, document_id TEXT FK, extracted_fields TEXT, confidence_scores TEXT, mode TEXT, custom_fields TEXT, status TEXT (CHECK constraint), session_id TEXT, created_at TEXT, updated_at TEXT

**memory_fts**: FTS5 virtual table (chunk_id, content, source_file, agent_id)

Key SQLite adaptations from v1 Postgres:
- UUIDs stored as TEXT (not UUID type)
- JSONB columns stored as TEXT (json.dumps/loads in Python)
- Timestamps as TEXT with datetime('now') defaults (not TIMESTAMPTZ)
- No user_id columns (single-tenant per sprite -- no RLS needed)
- No RPC functions (JSON path updates done in Python code)
- ocr_results uses ocr_file_path instead of raw_text (OCR cached at /workspace/ocr/)
- tags stored as TEXT (comma-separated or JSON array string) not TEXT[]

### v1 Database Pattern (What's Being Replaced)
- `backend/app/database.py` -- 13-line Supabase client singleton (lru_cache)
- Tool factory: `backend/app/agents/extraction_agent/tools/__init__.py` -- `create_tools(extraction_id, doc_id, user_id, db: Client)` returns list of scoped tool closures
- Supabase query style: `db.table("X").select("cols").eq("id", val).single().execute()`
- Supabase RPC: `db.rpc("update_extraction_field", params).execute()`

### How Downstream Task (m7b.3.2) Will Consume Database
Task m7b.3.2 expects: `db.query("SELECT ... WHERE ...")` style calls. The Database class needs to provide async methods that the tool factory can call with raw SQL + params.

## Implementation Guidance

### Recommended Class Design
Based on patterns observed in the codebase:

1. **Single async class `Database`** with these methods:
   - `__init__(self, db_path: str = "/workspace/agent.db")` -- configurable path for testing
   - `async connect(self)` -- open aiosqlite connection, enable WAL, run schema init
   - `async close(self)` -- close connection gracefully
   - `async execute(self, sql, params)` -- write operations (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE)
   - `async executemany(self, sql, params_list)` -- batch writes
   - `async fetchone(self, sql, params)` -- single row SELECT
   - `async fetchall(self, sql, params)` -- multi-row SELECT
   - `async query(self, sql, params)` -- alias or general-purpose method (m7b.3.2 expects this name)
   - Context manager support (`async with Database() as db:`)

2. **Schema initialization**: Embed the CREATE TABLE statements directly (matching bootstrap.ts exactly). Run on connect. Use IF NOT EXISTS for idempotency.

3. **WAL mode**: Set `PRAGMA journal_mode=WAL` immediately after connect. This allows concurrent reads while writing.

4. **Row factory**: Use `aiosqlite.Row` or return dicts (sqlite3.Row with dict() wrapper) so downstream tools get dict-like access to columns.

5. **Default path constant**: `DEFAULT_DB_PATH = "/workspace/agent.db"` -- override in tests with tmp_path.

### File Structure
- Create: `sprite/src/database.py` (~100-150 lines target)
- Create: `sprite/tests/test_database.py`

### Testing Pattern (Follow existing test_server.py)
- Use `pytest-asyncio` with `asyncio_mode = "auto"` (already configured in pyproject.toml)
- Use `tmp_path` fixture for isolated DB files (no /workspace/ dependency in tests)
- Test schema init, WAL mode, CRUD on each table, concurrent reads
- Import style: `from src.database import Database` (matches test_server.py pattern)

### Integration Points
- **server.py**: Will eventually create a Database instance and pass it to SpriteGateway
- **gateway.py**: Will pass Database reference to handlers which create agent tools
- **m7b.3.2 tools**: Will receive Database as `db` parameter in create_tools factory, replacing Supabase Client

## Risks

1. **SCHEMA.md says /workspace/data/stackdocs.db but everything else says /workspace/agent.db** -- The spec, bootstrap code, ops docs, and golden sprite all use `/workspace/agent.db`. SCHEMA.md line 82 is wrong. Builder should use `/workspace/agent.db` and SCHEMA.md should be updated separately (not part of this task).

2. **Bootstrap schema is in bridge/src/bootstrap.ts (TypeScript string literal)** -- The database.py schema MUST match this exactly, or sprites bootstrapped by Bridge will have a different schema than what database.py expects. Builder should copy the DDL from bootstrap.ts lines 51-89 verbatim.

3. **WAL mode needs verification on Sprite env** -- WAL works on most Linux systems but is worth verifying in tests. The task acceptance criteria explicitly requires PRAGMA journal_mode returning 'wal'.

4. **No migration system yet** -- Bootstrap creates tables, database.py will create tables on connect. When schema changes happen in future, there is no migration mechanism. For MVP this is fine (IF NOT EXISTS handles it), but worth noting.

5. **JSON fields stored as TEXT** -- extracted_fields, confidence_scores, tags, custom_fields are all TEXT columns containing JSON strings. The Database class should NOT handle serialization/deserialization -- that belongs in the tool layer (m7b.3.2). Database should pass TEXT through as-is.

6. **Connection handling** -- aiosqlite uses a single connection with thread-safe wrapper. For MVP (single connection, serialize writes), this is fine. The task description says "single connection for MVP, serialize writes". No pool needed.

comments.text:
[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

### Critical Architecture Decision (from m7b.3.2 close reason)
m7b.3.2 (Port tool factories) was closed as OBSOLETE. The v2 agent uses Bash, Read, Write, Edit, Grep, Glob as primary tools -- NOT custom tool factories. This fundamentally changes the implementation:
- **No MCP server registration for extraction tools.** The Claude Agent SDK (wrapping Claude Code CLI) comes with built-in tools (Bash, Read, Write, etc.) out of the box.
- **Custom tools needed only for:** Canvas updates (m7b.3.4, WebSocket messages) and OCR (Phase 4, external API call)
- **soul.md replaces prompts.py.** The system prompt is a file at `/workspace/memory/soul.md` that describes the schema, file locations, and extraction workflow.

### Claude Agent SDK Usage (v1 reference: `/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/backend/app/agents/extraction_agent/agent.py`)
Two usage patterns exist in v1:
1. **`query()` function** (spike_agent_sdk.py, spike_resume.py): Simple async generator, yields messages. Used for one-shot queries. Pattern: `async for message in query(prompt=..., options=...):`
2. **`ClaudeSDKClient` context manager** (spike_session.py, agent.py): Supports multiple queries in same session. Pattern: `async with ClaudeSDKClient(options=...) as client:` then `await client.query(prompt)` then `async for message in client.receive_response():`

**Key SDK types imported:**
- `ClaudeSDKClient` -- async context manager for multi-turn sessions
- `ClaudeAgentOptions` -- config: `system_prompt`, `mcp_servers`, `allowed_tools`, `max_turns`, `resume` (session_id)
- `AssistantMessage` -- contains `content: list[TextBlock | ToolUseBlock | ThinkingBlock]`, `model`, `error`
- `TextBlock` -- has `.text` (user-facing response)
- `ToolUseBlock` -- has `.name`, `.input`
- `ThinkingBlock` -- has `.thinking`
- `ResultMessage` -- has `.session_id`, `.total_cost_usd`, `.usage`, `.duration_ms`, `.num_turns`, `.is_error`
- `SystemMessage` -- has `.subtype`, `.data`
- `UserMessage` -- has `.content`
- `create_sdk_mcp_server()` -- registers custom tools as MCP server (may still be needed for Canvas tools)

**Session resume pattern** (from spike_resume.py): `ClaudeAgentOptions(resume=session_id, max_turns=1)` -- no system_prompt needed on resume (it was set in original session).

### Existing Sprite Code

**`/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/sprite/src/server.py` (59 lines)**
- WebSocket server on port 8765, handles single connection from Bridge
- Creates `SpriteGateway(send_fn=ws.send)` per connection
- Routes raw WS messages through `gateway.route(raw)`
- Graceful shutdown on SIGTERM/SIGINT

**`/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/sprite/src/gateway.py` (113 lines)**
- `SpriteGateway` class with `send_fn` (async callable), `mission_lock` (asyncio.Lock)
- Routes messages by type: mission, file_upload, canvas_interaction, heartbeat, auth, system
- **mission and heartbeat share the async lock** for serial execution
- `_handle_mission()` is a STUB (line 73-75): logs payload, sends ack. This is where runtime.py integration goes.
- Already has `_send_ack()` and `_send_error()` helpers that use protocol.py dataclasses

**`/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/sprite/src/protocol.py` (582 lines)**
- Complete dataclass definitions matching bridge/src/protocol.ts
- **AgentEvent** (line 265-271): type="agent_event", payload has `event_type` (text|tool|complete|error), `content` (str), optional `meta` (AgentEventMeta with extraction_id, session_id)
- **AgentEventPayload** (line 257-261): event_type, content, meta
- **AgentEventMeta** (line 250-253): extraction_id, session_id (both optional)
- `to_json()` function handles serialization including snake_case to camelCase for meta fields
- `to_dict()` function handles nested dataclasses and strips None values

**`/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/sprite/src/database.py` (109 lines)**
- `Database` class with async SQLite via aiosqlite
- Methods: `execute()`, `fetchone()`, `fetchall()`, `query` (alias for fetchall)
- Default path: `/workspace/agent.db`
- Used as async context manager
- **NOT in deployment list** (bootstrap.ts deploys only: __init__.py, server.py, gateway.py, protocol.py). Needs adding for runtime.py to use it.

### Protocol: AgentEvent Message Shape
```python
# Sprite -> Browser
AgentEvent(
    type="agent_event",
    payload=AgentEventPayload(
        event_type="text",      # "text" | "tool" | "complete" | "error"
        content="...",           # The text content or JSON-serialized tool info
        meta=AgentEventMeta(     # Optional
            extraction_id="...",
            session_id="...",
        ),
    ),
    request_id="...",  # References the mission message ID
)
```

### API Key Proxy Configuration (m7b.3.6 -- COMPLETE)
- Bridge has HTTP reverse proxy at `/v1/proxy/anthropic/*` and `/v1/proxy/mistral/*`
- Sprite env vars set via provisioning.ts `getEnvVarsForSprite()`:
  - `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL=https://ws.stackdocs.io/v1/proxy/anthropic`
  - `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=<SPRITES_PROXY_TOKEN>` (dummy key, replaced by Bridge)
  - `MISTRAL_BASE_URL=https://ws.stackdocs.io/v1/proxy/mistral`
  - `MISTRAL_API_KEY=<SPRITES_PROXY_TOKEN>`
- Claude Agent SDK reads `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL` and `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` from process env
- **No code change needed in runtime.py for API auth** -- it is transparent via env vars

### WS Message Flow (Browser -> Sprite -> Browser)
```
Browser sends: {"type":"mission","payload":{"text":"Extract this invoice"},...}
  -> Bridge forwards raw JSON to Sprite via TCP Proxy
  -> Sprite server.py receives, passes to gateway.route(raw)
  -> gateway._handle_mission() (currently stub, needs runtime.py call)
  -> runtime.py: parse mission text, build system prompt, invoke ClaudeSDKClient
  -> SDK streams AssistantMessage/ToolUseBlock/ResultMessage events
  -> runtime.py maps each event to AgentEvent dataclass, calls send_fn(to_json(event))
  -> gateway sends AgentEvent JSON over WS -> Bridge -> Browser
```

### Deployment: Files Must Be Added to bootstrap.ts
`/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/bridge/src/bootstrap.ts` line 27: `deployCode()` only deploys `['__init__.py', 'server.py', 'gateway.py', 'protocol.py']`. New files created by this task (runtime.py) and existing files needed (database.py) must be added to this list. CURRENT_VERSION must be bumped.

### Requirements: claude-agent-sdk Not in Sprite
`/Users/fraserbrown/stackdocs/sprite/requirements.txt` does NOT include `claude-agent-sdk`. Currently has: websockets, aiosqlite, anthropic, mistralai, httpx, pytest, pytest-asyncio. The `claude-agent-sdk>=0.1.17` package is only in `backend/requirements.txt`. Must be added to sprite requirements.

### Test Infrastructure (sprite/tests/)
- pytest with `asyncio_mode = "auto"` (pyproject.toml)
- No conftest.py -- fixtures defined per test file
- test_server.py uses real WebSocket server on free port (websockets serve/connect)
- test_database.py uses tmp_path for temp SQLite files
- Helper: `_msg()` function builds valid WS messages for testing
- Pattern: mock `send_fn` to capture outbound messages

## Implementation Guidance

### File: `sprite/src/runtime.py` (~150-200 lines)
Create an `AgentRuntime` class that:
1. Takes `send_fn` (from gateway) and `db` (Database instance)
2. Has `async def run_mission(text, request_id, attachments)` method
3. Builds system prompt from soul.md (read from `/workspace/memory/soul.md`)
4. Creates `ClaudeSDKClient` with `ClaudeAgentOptions`:
   - `system_prompt` from soul.md content
   - `allowed_tools` -- for MVP, the built-in tools are enough (Bash, Read, Write, etc. come free with Claude Code CLI). No MCP servers needed initially.
   - `max_turns` -- reasonable default (10-20 for autonomous work)
5. Calls `client.query(text)`
6. Iterates `client.receive_response()`, maps each message to AgentEvent:
   - `AssistantMessage` with `TextBlock` -> `AgentEvent(event_type="text", content=block.text)`
   - `AssistantMessage` with `ToolUseBlock` -> `AgentEvent(event_type="tool", content=json.dumps({"tool": block.name, "input": block.input}))`
   - `ResultMessage` -> `AgentEvent(event_type="complete", content=json.dumps({"session_id": msg.session_id}))`
   - Exception -> `AgentEvent(event_type="error", content=str(error))`
7. Stores `session_id` from ResultMessage for resume support
8. Has `async def resume_mission(text, session_id, request_id)` for corrections

### File: `sprite/src/gateway.py` (modify)
- Import and instantiate `AgentRuntime` (needs Database instance)
- In `__init__`, accept optional `db: Database` param, create `AgentRuntime(send_fn, db)`
- Replace `_handle_mission` stub with: extract text from payload, call `self.runtime.run_mission(text, request_id, attachments)`
- Gateway already has `mission_lock` ensuring serial mission execution

### File: `sprite/src/server.py` (modify)
- Create Database instance, pass to SpriteGateway constructor
- Database should be created once per server lifetime (not per connection)
- Use `async with Database() as db:` in `main()`, pass to `handle_connection`

### Bootstrap and Deployment Updates
- Add `database.py` and `runtime.py` to `deployCode()` file list in bootstrap.ts
- Add `claude-agent-sdk>=0.1.17` to sprite/requirements.txt
- Bump CURRENT_VERSION in bootstrap.ts

### Testing Strategy
- Mock `ClaudeSDKClient` to avoid real API calls
- Create mock that yields predefined AssistantMessage/ResultMessage sequences
- Test event mapping: SDK events -> correct AgentEvent types
- Test mission_lock: concurrent missions serialize (existing test pattern in test_server.py)
- Test error handling: exception in SDK -> agent_event with event_type="error"
- Test session resume: verify ClaudeAgentOptions(resume=session_id) is passed correctly

## Risks

### 1. claude-agent-sdk Dependency (High)
The package `claude-agent-sdk` is NOT in sprite/requirements.txt. It MUST be added. Verify it installs cleanly on Sprite VM (Ubuntu 25.04, Python 3.13.3). The SDK wraps the Claude Code CLI (`claude` binary) -- verify the CLI is available on the Sprite VM or is installed as a dependency of the SDK package.

### 2. Claude Code CLI on Sprite VM (High)
The Claude Agent SDK spawns `claude` as a subprocess. If the `claude` CLI binary is not installed on the Sprite VM, the SDK will fail at runtime. This needs verification -- either the SDK installs it as a dependency, or it must be installed separately during bootstrap. The Sprite golden image may not have it.

### 3. Task Description vs Architecture Decision Conflict (Medium)
The task description says "Register extraction tools via MCP server with allowed_tools whitelist" (step 3). But m7b.3.2 was closed as obsolete because v2 uses Bash/Read/Write directly. The Builder should follow the architecture decision (no extraction tool factories) rather than the task literal. Custom MCP tools are only needed for Canvas (m7b.3.4) and OCR (Phase 4). For m7b.3.3, no MCP servers should be registered.

### 4. Database Lifecycle (Medium)
Database instance needs to outlive individual WS connections (Sprite sleep/wake loses TCP but keeps processes). Currently server.py creates gateway per connection. The Database should be module-level or created in main() and passed through. If Bridge reconnects after sleep, a new gateway is created but should reuse the same Database.

### 5. Soul.md Loading (Low)
The task says "load memory -> build system prompt". But m7b.3.5 (memory system) is a separate downstream task. For m7b.3.3, use a minimal approach: read `/workspace/memory/soul.md` if it exists, fall back to a default system prompt. Full memory loading (user.md, journals, MEMORY.md) belongs to m7b.3.5.

### 6. Event Streaming Backpressure (Low)
If the agent generates events faster than the WS can send them, messages could queue in memory. For MVP this is unlikely to be an issue (WS latency ~200ms, events are small). Monitor post-MVP.

2. update_card(card_id, blocks) → build CanvasUpdate with command='update_card', validate card_id

title: Design API key proxy for Sprites (security)
description: Sprites should NEVER hold master API keys (ANTHROPIC_API_KEY, MISTRAL_API_KEY). Prompt injection in uploaded documents could exfiltrate keys via Bash or WebFetch tools. Design an API proxy route on Bridge: Sprite sets ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL to Bridge endpoint, Bridge adds the real key to outbound requests. Must be done before agent runtime (m7b.3.3) ships. Options: (A) HTTP proxy route on Bridge ~50-100 lines, (B) per-user scoped keys (provider support unclear), (C) separate proxy service.
close_reason: API key proxy implemented. HTTP reverse proxy on Bridge (api-proxy.ts, 130 lines, 10 tests). Anthropic + Mistral. Shared SPRITES_PROXY_TOKEN auth. Inspector: 10/10 pass.

[PATHFINDER] Codebase exploration complete

## Codebase Context

### Bridge HTTP Server (bridge/src/index.ts, lines 199-215)
- The Bridge creates a raw Node.js HTTP server via `createServer()`
- Currently has ONE HTTP route: `GET /health` (lines 201-209)
- All other HTTP requests return 426 Upgrade Required (lines 212-214)
- WebSocket upgrade happens on `server.on('upgrade')` handler (lines 219-235)
- **Adding new HTTP routes is trivial**: just add more `if` branches in the request handler before the 426 fallback

### Bridge Architecture Patterns
- **Module pattern**: Each concern in its own file (auth.ts, proxy.ts, keepalive.ts, etc.)
- **Environment variables**: Accessed via `process.env` (no config module)
- **Secrets on Fly.io**: Set via `flyctl secrets set`. Currently: CLERK_SECRET_KEY, SUPABASE_URL, SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY, SPRITES_TOKEN. NOT set: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY, MISTRAL_API_KEY (this task adds them)
- **Dependencies**: ws, uuid, @clerk/backend, @supabase/supabase-js. No HTTP request library -- uses native fetch (Node 22+)
- **Testing**: vitest, mocks external deps (Clerk, Supabase), real HTTP/WS server on test port
- **No existing HTTP proxy or middleware patterns** in the codebase

### Provisioning Already Prepared for This (bridge/src/provisioning.ts, lines 32-35)
- `getEnvVarsForSprite()` returns `{}` with an explicit comment: 'API keys are NOT injected as env vars -- prompt injection risk (see m7b.3.6). Phase 2 will add an API proxy route on Bridge instead.'
- This is where env vars for `buildExecUrl()` are set when starting the Python server process
- The exec URL supports `env` params that set environment variables on the Sprite process

### Anthropic SDK Base URL Configuration
- **Anthropic Python SDK**: Supports `base_url` constructor param AND `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL` env var
  - Example: `Anthropic(base_url='http://bridge:8080/v1/anthropic')`
  - Or: `export ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL=http://bridge:8080/v1/anthropic`
- **Claude Agent SDK**: Wraps the Claude Code CLI, which respects `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL` env var
  - ClaudeAgentOptions does NOT have a base_url param
  - But the underlying CLI reads `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL` from the process environment
  - This means: set the env var when launching the Sprite process via exec

### Mistral SDK Base URL Configuration
- **Mistral Python SDK (v1, Speakeasy-generated)**: Supports `server_url` constructor param
  - Example: `Mistral(api_key='dummy', server_url='http://bridge:8080/v1/mistral')`
  - No env var equivalent -- must be passed in code
  - Also accepts custom `client` (httpx.Client) or `async_client` (httpx.AsyncClient)

### v1 Agent Code (backend/app/agents/extraction_agent/agent.py)
- Uses `ClaudeSDKClient` from `claude_agent_sdk` with `ClaudeAgentOptions`
- Creates MCP servers via `create_sdk_mcp_server()`
- Tool factory pattern: `create_tools(extraction_id, document_id, user_id, db)`
- The ClaudeSDKClient handles all Anthropic API calls internally via the CLI

### Mistral OCR Usage (backend/app/services/ocr.py)
- Uses `Mistral(api_key=settings.MISTRAL_API_KEY)` -- lazy singleton
- Calls `client.ocr.process()` for OCR
- Runs in thread via `asyncio.to_thread()` (sync client)
- On Sprite, this would need `server_url` pointing to Bridge proxy

### Sprite Runtime (sprite/src/)
- Python WebSocket server on port 8765
- SpriteGateway routes messages, stub handlers only
- database.py has async SQLite wrapper
- requirements.txt already includes: anthropic>=0.42.0, mistralai>=1.0.0, httpx>=0.27.0
- **No runtime.py yet** -- that is m7b.3.3 (blocked by this task)

### Sprite-to-Bridge Connectivity
- Sprites connect to Bridge via TCP Proxy (WSS, Sprites.dev)
- Bridge connects to Sprites via TCP Proxy for WS messages
- **But the proxy route needs HTTP, not WS** -- Sprites must reach Bridge over the internet
- Bridge is at wss://ws.stackdocs.io (also https://ws.stackdocs.io for HTTP)
- Fly.io http_service config already handles HTTPS on port 8080

## Implementation Guidance

### Recommended Approach: HTTP Reverse Proxy on Bridge (~80-120 lines)

**New file: bridge/src/api-proxy.ts**
Create an HTTP handler function that:
1. Accepts POST requests on paths like `/v1/proxy/anthropic/*` and `/v1/proxy/mistral/*`
2. Validates a shared secret token (Sprite identity -- see auth below)
3. Reads the request body
4. Forwards to the real API (api.anthropic.com or api.mistral.ai) with the real API key injected
5. Streams the response back to the Sprite

**Modify: bridge/src/index.ts**
- In the `createServer` callback, add route matching before the 426 fallback
- Import and call the proxy handler for matching paths
- Pattern: `if (req.url?.startsWith('/v1/proxy/')) { return handleApiProxy(req, res); }`

**Sprite-side configuration** (two mechanisms):
1. **Anthropic (Claude Agent SDK)**: Set `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL=https://ws.stackdocs.io/v1/proxy/anthropic` as env var when launching the Sprite process. The env var is injected via the exec URL params in provisioning.ts `getEnvVarsForSprite()`
2. **Mistral**: In Sprite runtime code, init with `Mistral(api_key='sprite-token', server_url='https://ws.stackdocs.io/v1/proxy/mistral')`. Or set env var and read in code.

### Authentication: Sprite-to-Bridge
Options for authenticating proxy requests:
- **(A) Shared secret token**: Generate a per-sprite or global SPRITES_PROXY_TOKEN, injected as env var on Sprite. Sprite sends it as Bearer token in proxy requests. Bridge validates before forwarding. **Simplest, recommended for MVP.**
- **(B) Reuse SPRITES_TOKEN**: The Sprites.dev API token is already on Bridge. But it should NOT be on Sprites (it controls VM lifecycle).
- **(C) Per-stack signed JWT**: Bridge issues a short-lived JWT at connection time, Sprite uses it. More secure but more complex.

Recommendation: **(A)** with a single shared secret for MVP. Add per-stack tokens post-MVP.

### Files to Create/Modify
1. **CREATE** `bridge/src/api-proxy.ts` -- HTTP proxy handler (~80-120 lines)
2. **MODIFY** `bridge/src/index.ts` -- Add route to createServer callback (~5 lines)
3. **MODIFY** `bridge/src/provisioning.ts` -- Add env vars in `getEnvVarsForSprite()` (~5 lines)
4. **CREATE** `bridge/tests/api-proxy.test.ts` -- Test proxy routes
5. **Fly.io secret**: `flyctl secrets set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=... MISTRAL_API_KEY=... SPRITES_PROXY_TOKEN=...`

### Request Flow
```
Sprite (Python) --HTTPS--> Bridge (Fly.io) --HTTPS--> api.anthropic.com
                            |
                            +-- Validates SPRITES_PROXY_TOKEN
                            +-- Injects real ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
                            +-- Streams response back
```

### Key Implementation Details
- Use native `fetch()` (Node 22) for outbound requests to Anthropic/Mistral
- **Stream the response** -- Anthropic SDK uses SSE streaming for messages.create. The proxy must pipe response bodies, not buffer them. Use `res.pipe()` pattern or manual chunk forwarding.
- Anthropic API expects: `Authorization: Bearer sk-ant-...`, `x-api-key: sk-ant-...`, `anthropic-version: 2023-06-01`
- The proxy should pass through most headers from the Sprite request, replacing only auth headers
- Set appropriate CORS headers (none needed -- Sprite-to-Bridge is server-to-server)
- Add rate limiting per-sprite as a post-MVP concern

### Testing Pattern (from existing tests)
- Follow bridge/tests/server.test.ts pattern: vitest, mock external deps, real HTTP server
- Test: valid token forwards and returns response, invalid token returns 401, missing API key returns 503
- Mock the outbound fetch to Anthropic/Mistral

## Risks

### 1. Streaming Complexity (Medium)
The Anthropic Messages API uses SSE streaming. The proxy must forward the streaming response without buffering the entire body first. Node.js native `fetch()` returns a ReadableStream -- need to pipe it correctly to the HTTP response. Test with actual streaming to verify no data loss or latency spikes.

### 2. Mistral SDK server_url Behavior (Low-Medium)
The Mistral SDK's `server_url` param was found in Speakeasy-generated source code but is not well-documented. Need to verify at runtime that `Mistral(api_key='token', server_url='https://bridge/v1/proxy/mistral')` correctly prepends the server_url to API paths. If not, may need to use a custom httpx client instead.

### 3. Claude Agent SDK + ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL (Low)
The Claude Code CLI respects ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL, but verify this works for ALL API calls the SDK makes (messages, token counting, etc.). The env var approach is well-documented and widely used with proxy services.

### 4. Fly.io Machine Auto-Sleep (Low)
Bridge machine has auto_stop_machines='stop' and min_machines_running=0. When Sprite sends a proxy request, the Bridge Fly machine must be awake. Fly.io auto-starts on incoming HTTP requests, so this should work. But first request after sleep may have ~1-2s cold start latency.

### 5. Memory/CPU on Fly.io (Low)
Bridge is 256MB RAM, shared CPU. Proxying streaming API responses adds memory pressure. For MVP traffic this is fine. Monitor if multiple concurrent extractions cause issues.

### 6. Anthropic API Key Header Format (Low)
Anthropic uses BOTH `x-api-key` and `Authorization: Bearer` headers. The Python SDK uses `x-api-key`. The proxy must inject the correct header format. Check what the Anthropic SDK sends and match it.

### 7. ANTHROPIC_API_KEY on Sprite for Direct SDK Use (Clarification Needed)
The Claude Agent SDK (wrapping CLI) uses ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL + ANTHROPIC_API_KEY. The Sprite needs SOME api_key value for the SDK init even with a proxy. Options: (a) use the proxy token as the api_key value (proxy ignores it, uses real key), (b) use a dummy value. Need to verify the SDK/CLI behavior when api_key is set but base_url points to proxy.

title: Phase 3: Canvas UI — Grid Layout + Agent Prompt

Uses react-grid-layout for responsive dashboard layout — cards snap to grid, drag to rearrange, resize between predefined sizes (small/medium/large/full). No zoom/pan — scroll only.

- Predefined card sizes: small (1col), medium (2col), large (2col+), full (3col)
- Height auto-sizes to content
- No zoom, no pan — natural scroll
- `size` parameter replaces `card_type` (table/document/notes) in tool API
- Agent system prompt includes Canvas section with proactive card creation guidance
- Cards pop in complete (no streaming for MVP)
- Both user and agent can manage cards (create, close, resize, drag)
- Layout state in browser localStorage (Zustand + persist), no Sprite sync for MVP
- Responsive: 3 col desktop, 2 col tablet, 1 col mobile
- A2UI-inspired visual styling — clean, content-first

**Spec:** `.space-agents/exploration/ideas/2026-02-08-canvas-grid-layout-and-agent-prompt/spec.md`

### react-grid-layout v2.2.2 (latest, published 2025-12-30)
- **peerDependencies**: `react >= 16.3.0`, `react-dom >= 16.3.0` -- React 19 satisfies this
- **React 18/19 TS issues from v1 are FIXED in v2** -- confirmed by maintainer (STRML) on GitHub issue #2117

- **v2 has breaking API changes from v1** -- task description references v1 API patterns that won't work

### v2 API differences (critical for spike)
The task description says to use `<ResponsiveGridLayout>` and import CSS from `react-grid-layout/css/styles.css` + `react-resizable/css/styles.css`. This is the v2 pattern, confirmed correct:
- Import: `import { Responsive, useContainerWidth } from 'react-grid-layout'`
- No `WidthProvider` HOC -- replaced by `useContainerWidth()` hook
- `<Responsive>` component requires explicit `width` prop from the hook
- Must wrap in `<div ref={containerRef}>` and guard with `{mounted && ...}`
- CSS: two imports needed: `react-grid-layout/css/styles.css` + `react-resizable/css/styles.css`
- Package exports map: `./css/styles.css` is explicitly exported
- Layout items: `{ i: string, x: number, y: number, w: number, h: number }`
- Types: `LayoutItem` (single), `Layout` (array), `ResponsiveLayouts` (breakpoint map) -- import from `react-grid-layout` directly

### v2 config props of interest
- `gridConfig: { rowHeight: number }` -- controls row height
- `dragConfig: { enabled: boolean }` -- enable/disable drag
- `resizeConfig: { enabled: boolean }` -- enable/disable resize
- `compactType: 'vertical' | 'horizontal' | null` -- card compaction behavior
- `onLayoutChange: (layout, allLayouts) => void` -- persist layout changes

### CSS import approach
- Current pattern: `@xyflow/react/dist/style.css` imported in `stack-canvas.tsx` (component-level)
- Global CSS in `frontend/app/globals.css` (line 1-3) uses `@import` for tailwind, tw-animate, clerk
- For the spike: import CSS in the test-chat page component or at top of the grid component file

## Implementation Guidance

### Install command
`npm install react-grid-layout` (no `@types/react-grid-layout` needed -- v2 ships types)

### Spike structure on test-chat page
The test-chat page already has a two-panel layout (chat left, canvas right). For the spike, add a grid layout section below or beside the existing `<StackCanvas>` in the canvas panel area (lines 334-348). Keep existing React Flow canvas for comparison. The page uses `'use client'` already.

### v2 Responsive component pattern for the spike
```tsx
import { Responsive, useContainerWidth } from 'react-grid-layout'
import 'react-grid-layout/css/styles.css'
import 'react-resizable/css/styles.css'

// Inside component:
const { width, containerRef, mounted } = useContainerWidth()
// Wrap grid in <div ref={containerRef}>, guard with {mounted && <Responsive ...>}
```

### Auto-height testing (step 6 in task)
react-grid-layout uses fixed row heights. To auto-size card height to content:
- Use `ResizeObserver` on card content div
- Calculate `h = Math.ceil(scrollHeight / rowHeight)`
- Update layout item's `h` value
- This is the approach the task asks to validate

### Breakpoints for 3/2/1 col as specified
```
breakpoints: { lg: 1200, md: 768, sm: 0 }
cols: { lg: 3, md: 2, sm: 1 }
```

## Risks

1. **Task description references v1 API** -- says `<ResponsiveGridLayout>` but v2 uses `<Responsive>` + `useContainerWidth()` hook. Builder must use v2 patterns, not v1.
2. **CSS import in Next.js 16** -- importing CSS from `node_modules` in component files may need verification. Next.js supports this but Tailwind v4's `@import` syntax in globals.css is different from standard CSS imports. Spike will confirm.
3. **react-resizable CSS is a transitive dep** -- `react-resizable` is pulled in by `react-grid-layout` (not a direct dep). Its `css/styles.css` must be importable. Should work since it's in node_modules.
4. **Auto-height is the hardest part** -- react-grid-layout fundamentally uses fixed row heights. The ResizeObserver approach requires careful implementation to avoid infinite layout loops (content changes height -> triggers resize -> triggers layout change -> repeat). The spike needs to validate this specifically.

title: Test and verify full Bridge → Sprite connection path
description:
**Goal:** Fix Bridge → Sprite connection pipe so messages flow both directions.

**ROOT CAUSE (debugged Session 154):**

Three bugs, one root cause — nobody starts the Sprite Python server:

1. **`provisioning.ts`**: `bootstrapSprite()` deploys code but never starts the Python server. `buildServerExecUrl()` is defined (line 137) but never called.

2. **`proxy.ts` / `index.ts`**: Initial TCP Proxy connection failure (1011 = nothing listening on port 8765) has NO fallback. Bridge gives up instead of trying to start the server.

3. **`reconnect.ts`**: Has `defaultRestartServer` (line 112-122) that CAN start the server via exec, but only triggers after a previously-working connection drops — not on initial failure.

**Fix required:**

A) In `proxy.ts` `ensureSpriteConnection`: catch 1011 errors from `createAndRegister`, start server via exec (reuse `defaultRestartServer` pattern from reconnect.ts), retry connect.

B) In `provisioning.ts` `provisionSprite`: after `bootstrapSprite()`, start the Python server via exec before marking as active.

C) Tests: verify the retry logic works (mock 1011 → exec restart → successful connect).

**Key files:**
- `bridge/src/proxy.ts` — add retry-with-server-start to `ensureSpriteConnection`
- `bridge/src/provisioning.ts` — add server start after bootstrap
- `bridge/src/sprite-connection.ts` — no changes needed (working correctly)
- `bridge/src/reconnect.ts` — extract `defaultRestartServer` for reuse, or move to shared util
- `bridge/src/index.ts` — no changes needed (error handling is fine)

**Evidence:** Browser connects, auth succeeds, then: `Sprite connection failed: TCP Proxy closed during init: 1011`

**Server startup command** (from `provisioning.ts:30`):
```
cd /workspace && PYTHONPATH=/workspace/.os /workspace/.os/.venv/bin/python3 -m src.server
```

**Tests:**
- [ ] Initial connect starts server if not running (1011 → exec restart → connect succeeds)
- [ ] Provisioning starts server after bootstrap
- [ ] Existing reconnect logic still works (regression)
- [ ] Agent messages flow both directions through the pipe
close_reason: FIXED: Full E2E pipe working. Three fixes: (1) startSpriteServer shared utility in provisioning.ts, (2) 1011 retry in proxy.ts, (3) env vars fix in reconnect.ts. Also fixed venv symlink + VERSION on sd-e2e-test Sprite. Deployed to Fly.io. Agent creates cards → canvas_update flows through Bridge → card appears in browser. Blocks render as raw JSON — m7b.4.12.9 handles that.

- `.on(type: MessageType, handler): () => void` — per-type handlers (returns unsubscribe fn), NOT used by prototype
- `.status` getter — returns current ConnectionStatus
- Internal: `handleRawMessage()` calls `parseMessage()`, fires type-specific `.on()` handlers, then always fires `onMessage` callback
- Internal: `handleSystemMessage()` transitions status on `connected`/`sprite_waking`/`sprite_ready`/`error` events
- Auto-reconnect with exponential backoff (1s initial, 30s max, 2x multiplier)
- ConnectionStatus type: `'disconnected' | 'connecting' | 'authenticating' | 'sprite_waking' | 'connected' | 'error'`

### Prototype WS Pattern (`frontend/app/(app)/test-chat/page.tsx`, lines 233-333)
- `managerRef = useRef<WebSocketManager | null>(null)` — manager lives in ref, NOT state

- `handleMessage` (line 268): single `onMessage` callback dispatches by `message.type`:
  - `agent_event`: checks `event_type` — text (appends to last agent msg or creates new), tool/complete/error (adds system msg)

- `DesktopCard`: `{ id, title, blocks: Block[], position: { x, y }, zIndex }`

### Desktop Viewport (`frontend/components/desktop/desktop-viewport.tsx`, 272 lines)
- Exposes `current.current` (ref-based view state) — not directly accessible outside but synced to store via `scheduleSync`
- For auto-placer: viewport center = `window.innerWidth/2` and `window.innerHeight/2` in screen coords, then convert to world coords using `(screenX - view.x) / view.scale`

## Implementation Guidance

- Provider goes at `frontend/components/desktop/ws-provider.tsx`. Follow existing `components/providers/theme-provider.tsx` pattern for structure (though that one is trivial — just a wrapper).
- Mount provider in `frontend/app/(desktop)/stacks/[id]/page.tsx` wrapping the existing JSX. Pass `stackId={id}`.
- Port the ref-based pattern from test-chat: `useRef<WebSocketManager>()`, create in effect or connect callback, destroy on unmount.
- Message dispatch map: `canvas_update` -> desktop-store (`addCard` needs full DesktopCard with position from auto-placer, `updateCard` maps directly, `removeCard` maps directly); `agent_event` -> chat-store (`addMessage`/`appendToLastAgent`/`setAgentStreaming`); `system` -> internal status state.
- Auto-placer: no existing logic in codebase. Prototype just `flex-wrap`s cards. Desktop store requires `position: {x,y}` and `zIndex`. Auto-placer must compute position for `create_card` commands. Simple approach: offset from viewport center in a spiral/grid. Access viewport center via `useDesktopStore.getState().view` + `window.innerWidth/2`.
- `StatusUpdate` message type exists in protocol but is NOT dispatched anywhere in prototype — decide whether to handle or ignore in provider.
- For `useWebSocket()` hook return type: `{ status: ConnectionStatus, error: string | null, connect: () => void, disconnect: () => void, send: (msg) => boolean }`

## Risks

- **Demo card seeding conflict**: `stacks/[id]/page.tsx` seeds 5 demo cards on mount (lines 17-29). If WS also creates cards, they'll coexist. Builder should remove demo seeding or guard it behind `\!managerRef.current` / a feature flag.
- **Position gap**: `CanvasUpdate` payload has no position/zIndex fields. `DesktopCard` requires both. Auto-placer must bridge this gap for every `create_card`. If auto-placer fails to assign position, card renders at (0,0).
- **maxZIndex tracking**: desktop-store tracks `maxZIndex`. Auto-placer must use `state.maxZIndex + 1` for new cards to layer correctly.

title: Fix STT bugs (race condition, guards, error handlers, token TTL)

**Goal:** Eliminate orphaned mic streams, Deepgram connections, and keepAlive intervals caused by rapid start/stop, error events, and close events. Increase token TTL for longer recordings.

3. Add AbortController with 10s timeout on /api/voice/deepgram-token fetch
4. Deepgram Error handler: call full stopListening() cleanup (not just setError)
5. Deepgram Close handler: stop MediaRecorder + release mic tracks
6. Token TTL in deepgram-token/route.ts: 30s → 120s

**Tests:**
- [ ] startListening while already listening returns immediately
- [ ] Rapid start/stop/start: first session cleaned up, second works
